Award.AwardTitle: Deep Ocean Burning of Methane Hydrate

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1333605
Sirignano

A huge methane storehouse exists in methane hydrate sediments at the continental shelve edges in a permafrost state at depths of about a thousand meters at supercritical pressures for methane and air but subcritical for water. Oxygen or air can be delivered to depths for hydrate combustion for power and heat to melt and pump or to mine the hydrate. Methane hydrate burning with oxygen or air at the deep-ocean conditions (high pressures with water and fuel) will be simulated. Methane-water-air mixture oxidation at high pressures will be analyzed in a canonical configuration matching a planned experiment in a parallel, separately funded program: analysis of combustion and vaporization hydrate particle vaporization and combustion in oxygen, enriched air, or air. Substantial uncertainties about chemical and thermophysical properties will be analyzed through a stochastic framework, using the Polynomial Chaos Expansion approach. Collaborations will occur with the experimental team of the new UCI Deep Ocean Power Science Laboratory. Two pioneering aspects of this research within the energy and combustion science community are the study of combustion of hydrocarbons mixed with water (hydrates or clathrates) at deep ocean conditions and use of a stochastic framework to quantify the uncertainties. Graduate student researchers, including under-represented groups, will be attracted by the program novelty and educated through the substance. This research can contribute to future editions of Professor Sirignano's successful book. Participants will make presentations and work with the Summer Science program of the NSF-funded minority CAMP program and UCI COSMOS high-school-outreach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome - Grant CBET1333605                                                                                  “Deep Ocean Burning of Methane Hydrates” August 1, 2013 to July 31, 2016

The project addressed certain key scientific issues related to the burning of methane-hydrate fuels at pressures between one atmosphere and one hundred atmospheres. The huge resources of methane hydrate at ocean depths provide large potential economic benefits. The hydrates exist in an ice crystal form where there are approximately 5.7 molecules of water for every methane molecule. Burning at high pressures generally improves efficiency in converting the chemical energy of the fuel to useful electrical or mechanical energy.  Furthermore, burning some hydrate at ocean depth to provide energy for mining and/ or melting the majority of the hydrate must be done at the high pressures associated with depth.

Analysis of the combustion process at high pressures requires deviation from the various thermodynamic laws for an ideal fluid. This research has evaluated the importance of several corrections for analysis of real fluid behavior in a combustion environment for a given pressure and temperature: (i) determination of fluid density; (ii) evaluation of fluid internal energy and enthalpy; (iii) determination of density, internal energy, and enthalpy for a multicomponent mixture; (iv) evaluation of fluid viscosity and thermal conductivity; and (v) comparison of chemical equilibrium laws based on exact formulation with use of fugacity variable and approximate formulation using partial pressure. Preliminary work on phase equilibrium was also performed. Generally, these studies are also very relevant to the burning of conventional fuels at very high pressures, a trend underway because of increased efficiency. Furthermore, we identified the conditions under which certain effects can be neglected in the analysis: energy transport by radiation, transport of mass because of temperature gradients, and turbulent flow fluctuations.

An important issue to address is the burning of water-laden fuels. The methane hydrate will melt before mixing with air or oxygen and burning. Thus, liquid water, water vapor, and fuel can co-exist. As further heating occurs, a gaseous mixture of water and fuel is obtained.   In this research, we studied the burning of “wet fuel” over the full range of pressure between 1 - 100 atmospheres. The water vapor does affect flame temperature and heat release rates and can make flame extinction more likely. These effects were quantified. Note that hydrate burning is not the only situation where this information will be useful. Wet-fuel situations are of broader interest because of emulsified fuels, exhaust gas re-circulation, bio-fuels, and direct water injection into combustors.  

Two basic mathematical models were developed in the research to obtain the information described above. In one model, a melting solid methane-hydrate particle was surrounded by a layer with a bubbly mixture of liquid water and methane gas. In turn, there was an outer gaseous layer of water vapor, methane gas, and air. A flame establishes in the outer gaseous layer. After melting, the methane moves radially outward through the liquid layer and gaseous layer until it reaches the flame and is chemically transformed there.  In a second model, two opposing gas jet flows, one with methane and water vapor and the other with oxygen, met resulting in mixing of fuel and oxygen and development of a flame. In both of these models, equations were solved to determine the temperature, density, velocity, and chemical composition at each point in the flow, including within the flame.

While this study has not answered all questions about the burning of methane hydrates at high pressures, foundations for future research have been advanced.
